Georgia Gulf Chemicals, LLC Aberdeen PVC plant has a long history of safe operation in the Aberdeen community.  Our employees work hard every hour, every day to provide a safe workplace for themselves while protecting the environment inside and outside our fences.      

PLANT INFORMATION
The Aberdeen plant produces polyvinyl chlorine (PVC or vinyl) resins and compounds.  These materials are used in downstream operations to produce wire and cable insulation, vinyl siding, pipe, packaging, and numerous other similar products .  The resins and compounds are produced by the polymerization of vinyl chloride monomer (VCM).  After the polymerization, the resin is dried and stored for shipping.  Most of the VCM used in the process is shipped by rail from Georgia Gulf's Louisiana operations.  The VCM is a gas at normal conditions, but is kept under pressure and handled as a liquid, in a similar manner to propane.  At certain concentrations the VCM is flammable, therefore the plant has many safety systems in place.  Both the Flammable Chemical Vinyl Chlorine Monomer and the Toxic Chemical Chlorine, which isused as a water treatment additive, have been addressed in the RMP Plan preparation.

WORST-CASE SCENARIO
In calculating the "worst-case" scenario for flammable chemicals, the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA), requires the following assumptions be made:
Catastrophic (complete) failure of the largest storage vessel
Complete loss of the contents of the vessel and vaporization of the liquid in ten minutes
Mixing of sufficient air with the vapors to generate an explosion with a 10 percent yield-the worst seen for mixture of flammable vapors with air
None of the plant's procedures or emergency systems work
Ignition of the vapor cloud as soon as all the material vaporizes

The impact of these "worst-case" events decreases as you move away from the facility.  It is important to understand the standard measure of impact for determining the impacted zones.  These limits are d

eveloped by the EPA and are also used in the "alternate case" scenarios.  For flammable releases, the company is required to define the impacted areas within which one would see a shock wave of 1 pound per square inch (psi) overpressure, or in other words a wave significant enough to cause damage such as shattering of windows and partial demolition of houses.

The likelihood of a "worst-case" scenario is extremely remote and is of limited value for planning purposes.  This scenario defines the largest possible impacted zone.

VCM is unloaded from railcars and is stored in a spherical tank.  The capacity of this vessel is 6 million pounds of VCM.  If the vessel was completely full, ruptured, none of the safety systems functioned properly, it was a hot day and all the liquid vaporized in ten minutes, the atmospheric conditions provided sufficient oxygen without dispersing the vapor cloud, a spark set off an explosion, and the maximum explosive yield was generated, the off-site area impacted would consist of circle, centered in the processing unit, with a radius of 1.1 miles.

In calculating the "worst-case" scenario for toxic gases, the EPA requires the assumption that the total quantity in the single largest vessel or process line (passive mitigation measures may be taken into account) is released as a gas over a period of ten minutes.  In the "worst-case" scenario for the toxic chemical chlorine, a scenario in which the entire content of a back-up system comprised of two one-ton cylinders was released.  Assuming the length of the release is 10 minutes, the off-site area impacted would consist of a circle, centered at the utlities area, with a radius of 1.9 miles.

ALTERNATE RELEASE SCENARIO
Other release scenarios are also required to be considered.  The "alternate-case" scenarios generally involve smaller releases and take into account the mitigating ability of safety systems in determining the extent of impact.  The Aberdeen Plant's "alternate-case" VCM scenario a

ssumes that an 8-inch pipe on a vinyl chloride storage vessel in the production unit ruptures and allows the release of 486,000 pounds of vinyl chloride in 12 minutes.  It is assumed that the plant's gas detection system detects the release and sets off the plant's firewater system, which is assumed to "knock-down" half the vapor.  For this scenario, impact is limited to circle, centered around the vessel, with a radius of 0.2 miles.                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       The "alternate-case" scenario for Chlorine assumes that a one-ton cylinder releases all contents within 15 minutes.  For this scenario, impact is limited to a 0.2 mile radius originating at the release.. 

Georgia Gulf Chemicals and Vinyls, LLC Aberdeen plant is pround of the fact that we have never experienced any release resulting in damage to our neighbors.  With our safety systems and employees working every hour, every day, to prevent chemical accidents, we are confident of extending this record of safe operation.

ACCIDENT PREVENTION
Accident prevention is a large part of everyone's job at the Aberdeen Plant.  We work hard to make sure that our systems, procedures and people are all working together to prevent accidents from occurring.  To ensure safe operations of our plant, we have many systems in place including:

Engineering:
Stationary air monitors
Incinerators for combusting vapors
Relief valves for excess pressure
Emergency shut down procedures
Distributive control systems
Structural fireproofing
Back-up power supply
Automatic water spray systems
Tank containment systems

Operations:
Qualified personnel
Detailed training courses
Thorough operating procedures
24-hour instru

ment monitoring
All changes or work on equipment includes a complete review
Routine audits ensure safe work
Regular inspections of equipment
Incident reporting and investigations

Maintenance:
Preventative and predictive maintenance programs
Vibration monitoring
Infrared thermography
Corrosion monitoring programs
Detailed permitting procedures
Stationary vapor detection
Safe work procedures
Quality assurance/control

ACCIDENT HISTORY
The first incident in the plant's history to require reporting under the EPA's Risk Management Plan occurred in December of 2007.  Many changes, both operational and procedural, have been made since, in an attempt to decrease the likelihood of events such as this occuring.

EMERGENCY RESPONSE
Georgia  Gulf strives to be able to respond to any situation.  To accomplish this goal, our emergency preparedness efforts focus on four areas:

Personnel - The most important part of any response plan is well trainined, qualified people such as Georgia Gulf's voluntary Emergency Response Team (ERT).  The team consists of employees from various departments within the plant.  They train annually at places such as Texas A&M's school for firefighters and the Mississippi State Fire Academy.  On-site training is conducted regularly to test and refine the skills acquired at those facilities.  The ERT members have specialized training in fire fighting, hazardous materials handling, confined-space rescue and medical training.

Resources - The proper equipment is a necessary requirement for any job.  In the field of emergency response, it is necessary that equipment, materials, and labor be available immediately as needed.  The Aberdeen facility is equipped with such items as chemical transportation response equipment, automatically activated fire water systems, portable fire water monitors, fire fighting gear, fire extinguishers and other necessary equipment.

Although it is hoped they will never be necessary, Georgia Gulf Chemicals & Vinyls, LLC has provi

ded sirens to alert the community to off-site emergencies.  These sirens are located in the community and are controlled by the Aberdeen Police Department.  The community may use them in case of severe weather, chemical accidents, or any situation requiring action.

Planning - Complete plans are a must to help guide people and resources in the event of an emergency.  Georgia Gulf Chemcials and Vinyls, LLC has plans in place to handle on-site and off-site incidents.  Our plans have been developed in coordination with the Local Emergency Planning Commission.

Alliances - To provide for additional resources in the event of a major incident, the Aberdeen plant has agreements with the Aberdeen Fire Department and local emergency medical responders to provide additional resources if required.  These potential responders are given tours of the plant and are familiarized with processes at the plant in the event they are called on to provide assistance.
